description:
Carya illinoinensis, commonly known as the pecan tree, is a species of hickory native to the south-central region of North America. It is a large, deciduous tree that can reach heights of up to 40 meters (130 feet) and have a trunk diameter of up to 2 meters (6.6 feet).

The leaves of the pecan tree are compound, with 9-17 leaflets that are oblong to lanceolate in shape and have serrated edges. The bark of the tree is gray and furrowed, often with a scaly appearance.

The pecan tree produces edible nuts that are enclosed in a hard, oblong shell. The nuts are a popular food source and are widely cultivated for commercial production. The wood of the pecan tree is also valued for its strength and durability, and is used in the production of furniture, flooring, and other wood products.

Carya illinoinensis is an important ecological and economic species, providing food and habitat for a variety of wildlife, as well as being a valuable crop for human consumption and industrial use.
